bestBHT.bht: The interruption by the standers-by in surprise at the decision to give the one pound to the man who already has ten pounds shows how deeply invested they were in understanding Jesus' teachings. The subsequent explanation reveals that the faithful who make the most of what God gives will receive even greater abundance. This expression of surprise highlights the admiration, rather than envy, of the most eminent and useful servants of Christ. Their reaction underscores the significance of faithfully stewarding God's gifts.

Henry Alford: 25.] is parenthetical, spoken by the standers-by in the parable, in surprise at such a decision: then in ver. 26, the king answers them.
Albert Barnes: He has already ten pounds. Why take away this one, and add to what he already possesses? Why should his property be increased at the expense of this man, who has but one pound?
The answer to this is given in the following verse; that every one that hath, to him shall be given; every man who is faithful, and improves what God gives him, shall receive much more.
Every man who is faithful, and improves what God gives him, shall receive much more.
Philip Schaff: This expression of surprise was probably introduced to bring out the answer of the King.
Archibald T. Robertson: Probably the eager audience who had been listening to this wonderful parable interrupted Jesus at this point because of this sudden turn when the one pound is given to the man who has ten pounds.
If so, it shows plainly how keenly they followed the story which Jesus was giving because of their excitement about the kingdom (Luke 19:11).
They were deeply invested in understanding the principles and teachings of Jesus.
John Gill: It is generally the lot of the most eminent and useful servants of Christ to be envied by others."
Surprise, as wondering at the conduct of Christ in giving more to such, who had so much already.
This verse is left out in Beza's most ancient copy. However, it is rightly put into a parenthesis in our version.
John Wesley: They said — With admiration, not envy.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 19:25, the standers-by in the parable express surprise at the decision to give the one pound to the man who already has ten pounds. Their interruption reveals their keen investment in understanding the principles and teachings of Jesus. The answer to their surprise is given in the following verse, emphasizing that those who are faithful and improve what God gives them will receive much more. This expression of surprise was likely included to bring out the King's response. Ultimately, this passage highlights how the most eminent and useful servants of Christ may be envied by others, with the reaction of the standers-by being one of admiration rather than envy.

The interruption by the standers-by in surprise at the decision to give the one pound to the man who already has ten pounds reveals their deep investment in understanding Jesus' teachings. The subsequent explanation emphasizes that the faithful who make the most of what God gives them will receive even greater abundance. This expression of surprise highlights the admiration, rather than envy, of the most eminent and useful servants of Christ. Ultimately, their reaction underscores the significance of faithfully stewarding God's gifts.

The interruption by those listening in astonishment at the decision to give the one pound to the man who already has ten pounds indicates their deep investment in understanding Jesus' teachings. The subsequent explanation emphasizes the reward for faithfulness and making the most of what God provides. This surprise highlights the admiration, rather than envy, of the most eminent servants of Christ. Their reaction underscores the importance of faithfully stewarding God's gifts.
